instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study on estimating soil heavy metal contents using the PSO-BPNN method?
Output: In the related study, both field spectral data and hyperspectral imagery were used to estimate the soil heavy metal contents using the PSO-BPNN method.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to estimate the soil heavy metal contents in the related study?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to estimate the soil heavy metal contents in the related study included smoothing spectral data using a Savitzky-Golay filter, correlation analysis of raw spectral data and transformed spectral variables, and combining spectral variables through addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operations.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the estimation accuracy of the PSO-BPNN method and how far can this metric go in the related study on estimating soil heavy metal contents using the PSO-BPNN method?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the estimation accuracy of the PSO-BPNN method is the mean relative error (MRE) and relative root mean square error (RRMSE). The study found that the PSO-BPNN method significantly improved the estimation accuracy of the soil heavy metal contents, with a decrease in MRE and RRMSE by 68% to 71% and 64% to 67%, respectively. This indicates that the PSO-BPNN method has the potential to provide more accurate estimates of soil heavy metal contents. instruction: How did the study aim to improve the estimation accuracy of soil heavy metal contents using the combination of back propagation neural network (BPNN) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) methods?
Output: The study aimed to improve the estimation accuracy of soil heavy metal contents by combining the back propagation neural network (BPNN) with particle swarm optimization (PSO) methods. This combination, known as the PSO-BPNN method, was used to estimate the contents of soil heavy metals, specifically Cd, Hg, and As. By integrating PSO with BPNN, the researchers aimed to enhance the accuracy of the estimation process.

instruction: How did the combination of back propagation neural network (BPNN) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) methods improve the estimation accuracy of soil heavy metal contents in the study?
Output:
In the study, the combination of back propagation neural network (BPNN) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) methods, referred to as the PSO-BPNN method, was used to estimate the contents of soil heavy metals (Cd, Hg, and As). The PSO-BPNN method significantly improved the estimation accuracy of the soil heavy metal contents compared to using only BPNN. 

The improvement in estimation accuracy was demonstrated by a decrease in the mean relative error (MRE) and relative root mean square error (RRMSE) by 68% to 71% and 64% to 67%, respectively. This indicates that the PSO-BPNN method provided a more accurate estimation of the soil heavy metal contents.

Additionally, the PSO-BPNN method showed great potential for mapping the heavy metal content in soil. It was able to map the Cd content using HuanJing-1A Hyperspectral Imager (HSI) data with a RRMSE value of 36%. This suggests that the PSO-BPNN method can be utilized to estimate and map soil heavy metal contents in large areas using both field spectral data and hyperspectral imagery.
